At that time, he was following his disciples and great beings, staying in a place of pleasant sounds, widely opening [the Dharma].

You should recognize its fewness.
The causes and conditions of all dharmas, those who recognize it are rare.
It is like drilling wood to make fire, the two pieces of wood rub against each other.
The fire does not come from the drill, nor does it come from the flint.
The fire appears in between, shining brightly, and returns to burn the wood, the wood is exhausted and disappears.
It is also like a drum being beaten, its sound is mournful and destructive.
The sound does not come from the leather, nor from the mallet.
All dharmas are like this, mutually dependent in their characteristics.
It is also like rain from the heavens, where wind, clouds, thunder, and lightning come together to make rain, not solely the power of the dragon.
All dharmas are like this, and so is the text.
It is like a painter who mixes the colors, and then adds the lines, without any form not immediately present, all requiring the combination of conditions, not the power of one alone.
